comment: Although Shirov has played a variety of defenses, I think he's been playing the Petroff's Defense and perhaps the Caro-Kann most recently.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5
comment: Neo-Sveshnikov or Lowenthal leaves d5 (and perhaps d6) weak. More common is 4...Nf6, forcing White to defend Pe4 and threatening ...d5.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3
comment: He threatens Nc3-d5 and Nc7+, so Black must nip that idea in the bud.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5
comment: Instead of White dominating square c4 it's Black who controls it, for the moment. Eventually piece play should dominate a position more than pawns. There is also the immediate threat of ...b4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5
comment: White could continue with Bc1-e3-b6 and Nc7+, so Black has to react quickly.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5
comment: This makes the pawns a bit unbalanced with White advancing on the queen-side. Aside from Pb5 Black shouldn't have much difficulty completing his development.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4
comment: Now White controls c4!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4
comment: aiming for a4-a5 and Nb6 or Bb6 to cramp Black, but making Pb2 backward! That and the slightly exposed Pd5 make White's position suspicous. Where's his offense coming from? I suppose he thinks it's necessary to use a Nb6 to defend Pd5, but ...Nf6-d7 can chase a Nb6 away, exposing Pb2. If he continues his queen-side advance then one of the pawns gives him the advantage. So, where's Black's offense come from?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7
comment: The bishop is badly placed on the b-file.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7
comment: There it is! But, does it really work?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7
comment: keeping a foot planted firmly on both the queen- and king-side and preparing some kind of king-side offensive

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4
comment: If it's backward then trade it off. In this case b4-b5xa6 would make a passed pawn; ...a6xb5 does the same.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6
comment: threatening ...f4 and ...e5-e4-e3, but once that threat is avoided then what is Bf6 doing?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1
comment: Keeping the rook on the a-file, to back up Pa5, might be appealing, but Pb4 needs more immediate support.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4
comment: Mostly desperation I think. White's offense is rolling along nicely and Black has none.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4
comment: White doesn't want to play f3-f4 and leave Black with a protected passed pawn at e4. And, I understand that feeling. However, to open lines means to give Black other possibilities.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4
comment: defending Pe4 and threatening Be2-b5 or a5-a6 seems correct

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3
comment: Now begins a forcing sequence. White doesn't want to move Rb4, so he threatens Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3 27. Bb5 Qd8 28. Bxe8 Bxb4
comment: Now what? Be8 and Pa5 are threatened. Obviously Be8 needs to move and threaten something or White needs to threaten Bb4 or Kg8.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3 27. Bb5 Qd8 28. Bxe8 Bxb4 29. Bc6 Ba6
comment: If Black can't trade off Bb7 then he's just lost a valuable tempo and White can take the advantage in the center by capturing Pf5. Pa5 becomes a casualty of the campaign.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3 27. Bb5 Qd8 28. Bxe8 Bxb4 29. Bc6 Ba6 30. Rxf5 Bxa5 31. h3 Rb8 32. Kh2
comment: tries to make the king safer, but might be wasting a valuable tempo

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3 27. Bb5 Qd8 28. Bxe8 Bxb4 29. Bc6 Ba6 30. Rxf5 Bxa5 31. h3 Rb8 32. Kh2 g6
comment: Why weaken the king's position when there is still room for piece activity improvements.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3 27. Bb5 Qd8 28. Bxe8 Bxb4 29. Bc6 Ba6 30. Rxf5 Bxa5 31. h3 Rb8 32. Kh2 g6 33. Bg5 Qc7 34. Rf3
comment: After this it's difficult to find a good move for Black, despite there being no direct threat.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 e5 5. Nb5 d6 6. N1c3 a6 7. Na3 b5 8. Nd5 Nce7 9. c4 Nxd5 10. exd5 bxc4 11. Nxc4 Nf6 12. Be3 Rb8 13. Be2 Be7 14. a4 O-O 15. O-O Bb7 16. Nb6 Nd7 17. a5 f5 18. f3 Nxb6 19. Bxb6 Qd7 20. b4 Bd8 21. Be3 Bf6 22. Rb1 Rbc8 23. b5 axb5 24. Rxb5 e4 25. fxe4 Rfe8 26. Rb4 Bc3 27. Bb5 Qd8 28. Bxe8 Bxb4 29. Bc6 Ba6 30. Rxf5 Bxa5 31. h3 Rb8 32. Kh2 g6 33. Bg5 Qc7 34. Rf3 Rb4 35. Bh6 Rb8 36. Qa1 Be2 37. Rf2 Bd3 38. Qf6
comment: and checkmate is unavoidable. The weakening ...g6 has to be blamed for part of this mess.
